items.title: Functions exec_start and exec_create aren't anymore part of DockerClient object
items.body:
If you try to use:
dockerpty.exec_command(client, container, 'sh', interactive=True, stdout=True, stderr=True, stdin=True)
or likewise dockerpty.start_exec...

```AttributeError: 'DockerClient' object has no attribute 'exec_create' In Docker SDK for Python 2.0, this method is now on the object APIClient. See the low-level API section of the documentation for more details.```

You could check also here: 
https://docker-py.readthedocs.io/en/stable/api.html#module-docker.api.exec_api

I will be glad to fix it..

items.title: Need support for custom detachKeys
items.body:
I'm an emacs user and every time I want to use ctrl-p, I have to type it twice since ctrl-p is the prefix of the detachKeys.
docker already has a config file which can change the detachKeys, docker/docker#3519. But it doesn't work in docker-compose.

Someone who also get trouble in this issue. #62

items.title: Attaching to docker containers fails when specifying a log driver
items.body:
I came here from https://github.com/docker/compose/issues/2448 since I'm bitten by the same issue. @glenbot [pointed out](https://github.com/docker/compose/issues/2448#issuecomment-161722916) that the problem is caused by [pty.py:188](https://github.com/d11wtq/dockerpty/blob/master/dockerpty/pty.py#L188) where the docker client is used to attach to the socket. Here dockerpty specifies `'logs': 1` which breaks when the container is running with a log driver.

Here's an example program that exercises the issue:

``` python
import dockerpty
import docker
from docker.utils import kwargs_from_env

client = docker.Client(**kwargs_from_env())
container = client.create_container(
    image='busybox:latest',
    stdin_open=True,
    tty=True,
    command='/bin/sh',
    host_config={"LogConfig": {
        "Type": "none"
    }}
)

dockerpty.start(client, container['Id'], interactive=True)
```

I've verified that changing the value of logs to 0 makes the test program work as expected.

items.title: dockerpty causing docker-compose run to exit with return code 1?
items.body:
Hi,

I have this issue open on docker/compose and I think it might possibly belong here. I've tried looking around but I can pinpoint the problem. Can anyone help?

https://github.com/docker/compose/issues/1424

Thanks!

items.title: Is dockerpty ready for a 0.3.3 release?
items.body: @d11wtq, @aanand  do you think that dockerpty is ready for a 0.3.3 release? I'd love to bring the newest changes into the fedora repos. I have [this bugzilla report](https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1172357) already way too long open ;)

items.title: Streams closing due to recoverable errors when reading
items.body:
I've observed my streams closing due to recoverable errors (generally EWOULDBLOCK) when reading.

`Stream.write` sits in a while loop to retry after recoverable errors, is there a reason `Stream.read` doesn't?  I've had success modifying `Stream.read` to sit in a while loop, but am worried that I'm missing a corner case.

items.title: support for exec
items.body: This library works great for start(). Could we get support for dockerclient.execute()?

items.title: Randomly truncated output
items.body:
Given this script:

``` python
#!/usr/bin/env python

from docker.client import Client
from docker.utils import kwargs_from_env
import dockerpty

client = Client(**kwargs_from_env())
container = client.create_container(image="debian:wheezy", stdin_open=True, tty=True, command='seq 200')
dockerpty.start(client, container)
```

When I run it, about half the time I see the full output (1..200, each on their own line), and the other half the time it just prints "1" (with no newline) and exits:

``` bash
zach $ ./test.py 
1zach $ 
```

I'm using boot2docker on OS X, if that makes a difference. I tried against https://github.com/d11wtq/dockerpty/pull/25 as well, thinking it may be related, but still get the truncated output. Originally noticed using fig: https://github.com/docker/fig/issues/658.

items.title: Feature Failure in dockerpty-0.2.4
items.body:
I'm packaging up dockerpty for Gentoo. While running the tests that include docker, I came across only one failure.  I'm having a hard time determining if the failure was caused by the system or something in the code and am petitioning here for a few pointers as to what causes of this particular failure might be:

```
  Scenario: Resizing the PTY frenetically                # features/interactive_terminal.feature:101
    Given I am using a TTY with dimensions 20 x 70       # features/steps/step_definitions.py:36
    And I run "/bin/sh" in a docker container with a PTY # features/steps/step_definitions.py:42
    When I start dockerpty                               # features/steps/step_definitions.py:74
    And I resize the terminal to 30 x 100                # features/steps/step_definitions.py:102
    And I resize the terminal to 30 x 101                # features/steps/step_definitions.py:102
    And I resize the terminal to 30 x 98                 # features/steps/step_definitions.py:102
    And I resize the terminal to 28 x 98                 # features/steps/step_definitions.py:102
    And I resize the terminal to 28 x 105                # features/steps/step_definitions.py:102
    And I wait 3 seconds                                 # features/steps/step_definitions.py:135
    And I type "stty size"                               # features/steps/step_definitions.py:113
    And I press ENTER                                    # features/steps/step_definitions.py:118
    Then I will see the output                           # features/steps/step_definitions.py:141
      """
      / # stty size
      28 105
      / #
      """
      Assertion Failed: Expected ['/ # stty size', '30 100', '/ #'] to equal [u'/ # stty size', u'28 105', u'/ #']
```

My first thoughts are that the system was not performing as expected and the three second delay is not enough to consistently make this test pass.  I just want to get some confirmation that this hypothesis is reasonable and I will be doing a follow up test if necessary with a longer sleep.  The entire build log is here, https://bpaste.net/show/fbb5749bac95, if needed.

Since everything else passes, I assume I can conclude that the packaging is correct and the environment is properly configured but I would also like someone else's confirmation.

Any guidance is appreciated and thanks in advance.

items.title: Attaching over TLS produces raw output
Support docker-py in TLS mode
items.body:
There is ongoing work to get fig working with TLS/https enabled (https://github.com/docker/fig/issues/218). I'm trying to make this work but hitting an issue in dockerpty where the sockets returned from docker-py's client.attach_socket() method are assumed to be plain python sockets. When docker-py is connected to the remote API via a TLS/https connection, these returned objects are actually ssl.SSLSocket objects. They seem to be throwing an exception when dockerpty calls fileno() on these sockets:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/bin/fig", line 9, in <module>
    load_entry_point('fig==0.5.2', 'console_scripts', 'fig')()
  File "/Library/Python/2.7/site-packages/fig/cli/main.py", line 30, in main
    command.sys_dispatch()
  File "/Library/Python/2.7/site-packages/fig/cli/docopt_command.py", line 21, in sys_dispatch
    self.dispatch(sys.argv[1:], None)
  File "/Library/Python/2.7/site-packages/fig/cli/command.py", line 30, in dispatch
    super(Command, self).dispatch(_args, *_kwargs)
  File "/Library/Python/2.7/site-packages/fig/cli/docopt_command.py", line 24, in dispatch
    self.perform_command(_self.parse(argv, global_options))
  File "/Library/Python/2.7/site-packages/fig/cli/command.py", line 51, in perform_command
    handler(project, command_options)
  File "/Library/Python/2.7/site-packages/fig/cli/main.py", line 295, in run
    dockerpty.start(project.client, container.id)
  File "/Library/Python/2.7/site-packages/dockerpty/**init**.py", line 27, in start
    PseudoTerminal(client, container).start()
  File "/Library/Python/2.7/site-packages/dockerpty/pty.py", line 144, in start
    flags = [io.set_blocking(p, False) for p in pumps]
  File "/Library/Python/2.7/site-packages/dockerpty/io.py", line 31, in set_blocking
    old_flag = fcntl.fcntl(fd, fcntl.F_GETFL)
  File "/Library/Python/2.7/site-packages/dockerpty/io.py", line 248, in fileno
    return self.from_stream.fileno()
  File "/Library/Python/2.7/site-packages/dockerpty/io.py", line 101, in fileno
    return self.fd.fileno()
  File "/System/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/socket.py", line 224, in meth
    return getattr(self._sock,name)(_args)
  File "/System/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/socket.py", line 170, in _dummy
    raise error(EBADF, 'Bad file descriptor')
socket.error: [Errno 9] Bad file descriptor

There is ongoing work to get fig working with TLS/https enabled (https://github.com/docker/fig/issues/218). I'm trying to make this work but hitting an issue in dockerpty where the sockets returned from docker-py's client.attach_socket() method are assumed to be plain python sockets. When docker-py is connected to the remote API via a TLS/https connection, these returned objects are actually ssl.SSLSocket objects. items.title: Test failure - Resizing the PTY frenetically
items.body:
This test fails for me on master. I tried in tmux and in a regular terminal. It appears to be passing on travis.

```
  Scenario: Resizing the PTY frenetically                # features/interactive_terminal.feature:101
    Given I am using a TTY with dimensions 20 x 70       # features/steps/step_definitions.py:36 0.000s
    And I run "/bin/sh" in a docker container with a PTY # features/steps/step_definitions.py:42 0.127s
    When I start dockerpty                               # features/steps/step_definitions.py:74 0.209s
    And I resize the terminal to 30 x 100                # features/steps/step_definitions.py:102 0.000s
    And I resize the terminal to 30 x 101                # features/steps/step_definitions.py:102 0.000s
    And I resize the terminal to 30 x 98                 # features/steps/step_definitions.py:102 0.000s
    And I resize the terminal to 28 x 98                 # features/steps/step_definitions.py:102 0.000s
    And I resize the terminal to 28 x 105                # features/steps/step_definitions.py:102 0.000s
    And I wait 3 seconds                                 # features/steps/step_definitions.py:135 3.003s
    And I type "stty size"                               # features/steps/step_definitions.py:113 0.000s
    And I press ENTER                                    # features/steps/step_definitions.py:118 0.000s
    Then I will see the output                           # features/steps/step_definitions.py:141 4.005s
      """
      / # stty size
      28 105
      / #
      """
      Assertion Failed: Expected ['/ # stty size', '30 100', '/ #'] to equal [u'/ # stty size', u'28 105', u'/ #']
```

items.title: Error while running under python 3.4
items.body:
```
$ fig run console bash
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "...fig/.tox/py34/lib/python3.4/site-packages/dockerpty/pty.py", line 143, in start
    flags = [io.set_blocking(p, False) for p in pumps]
  File "...fig/.tox/py34/lib/python3.4/site-packages/dockerpty/pty.py", line 143, in <listcomp>
    flags = [io.set_blocking(p, False) for p in pumps]
  File "...fig/.tox/py34/lib/python3.4/site-packages/dockerpty/io.py", line 31, in set_blocking
    old_flag = fcntl.fcntl(fd, fcntl.F_GETFL)
ValueError: file descriptor cannot be a negative integer (-1)

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "...fig/.tox/py34/bin/fig", line 9, in <module>
    load_entry_point('fig==0.5.2', 'console_scripts', 'fig')()
  File "...fig/.tox/py34/lib/python3.4/site-packages/fig/cli/main.py", line 30, in main
    command.sys_dispatch()
  File "...fig/.tox/py34/lib/python3.4/site-packages/fig/cli/docopt_command.py", line 21, in sys_dispatch
    self.dispatch(sys.argv[1:], None)
  File "...fig/.tox/py34/lib/python3.4/site-packages/fig/cli/command.py", line 28, in dispatch
    super(Command, self).dispatch(*args, **kwargs)
  File "...fig/.tox/py34/lib/python3.4/site-packages/fig/cli/docopt_command.py", line 24, in dispatch
    self.perform_command(*self.parse(argv, global_options))
  File "...fig/.tox/py34/lib/python3.4/site-packages/fig/cli/command.py", line 49, in perform_command
    handler(project, command_options)
  File "...fig/.tox/py34/lib/python3.4/site-packages/fig/cli/main.py", line 263, in run
    dockerpty.start(project.client, container.id)
  File "...fig/.tox/py34/lib/python3.4/site-packages/dockerpty/__init__.py", line 27, in start
    PseudoTerminal(client, container).start()
  File "...fig/.tox/py34/lib/python3.4/site-packages/dockerpty/pty.py", line 147, in start
    if flags:
UnboundLocalError: local variable 'flags' referenced before assignment
```

The flags error seems easy enough to fix (just set it to None before the try/except).

The other one looks to be caused by this:

```
pumps:

stdin: (Stream(<_io.TextIOWrapper name='<stdin>' mode='r' encoding='UTF-8'>), Stream(<socket.socket [closed] fd=-1, family=AddressFamily.AF_UNIX, type=SocketType.SOCK_STREAM, proto=0>)), 

stdout: (Stream(<socket.socket [closed] fd=-1, family=AddressFamily.AF_UNIX, type=SocketType.SOCK_STREAM, proto=0>), Stream(<_io.TextIOWrapper name='<stdout>' mode='w' encoding='UTF-8'>)), 

stderr: (Stream(<socket.socket [closed] fd=-1, family=AddressFamily.AF_UNIX, type=SocketType.SOCK_STREAM, proto=0>), Stream(<_io.TextIOWrapper name='<stderr>' mode='w' encoding='UTF-8'>))

```

items.title: Fig + dockerpty + Jenkins = no stdout
items.body: I use fig in Jenkins, and when I use "fig run" there is no stdout on Jenkins, the problem seems to come from your module. Do you have an idea?

items.title: OSError: 11 - Resource temporarily unavailable
items.body:
When spewing a lot of data into the console very quickly and simultaneously hitting keyboard input, I got a crash:

```
OSError: [Errno 11] Resource temporarily unavailable
```

This was raised from `io.Stream.flush()`. We should probably consider this a transient failure and rescue it.
